case_name: Sri-la-Sri Subramania Desika Gnana Sambanda Pandarasannadhi, Hereditary Trustee of the Rajan Kattalai v. State of Madras

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 560 of 1964 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated August 11, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 295 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CIVIl. APPEAL No. 560 or 1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 11, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 295, of 1958.

facts.text: On August 4, 1956, the Governor of Madras issued a notification under sub-section 4 of s. 64 of the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 directing that notification No. 638 dated May 25, 1937 relating to Sri Thiyagarajaswami Temple be continued for five years from September 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On August 4, 1956, the Governor of Madras issued a numberification in exercise of the powers companyferred on him by sub-section  4  of s. 64 of the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act. 1951  Madras Act XIX of 1951  directing that numberification No. 638, dated the 25th May, 1937. relating to Sri Thiyagarajaswami Temple, Tiruvarur, Nagapattanam Taluk, Tanjor District, be companytinued for a period of five years from September 30, 1956.

facts.text: Notification No. 638 dated May 25, 1937 was issued by the State of Madras under clause b of sub-section 5 of s.65A of the Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1926 declaring the temple and endowments subject to Chapter VI-A.

anchor.surface_text: The earlier numberification which was thus companytinued had itself been issued by the respondent State of Madras in exercise of the powers companyferred on it by clause  b  of sub-section  5  of s.65A of the Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1926  Madras Act 1I of 1927 . declaring that the temple in question and the specific endowments attached thereto shall be subject to the provisions of Chapter VI-A of the said Act.

facts.text: Appellant Sri-la-Sri Subramania Desika Gnana Sambanda Pandarasannadhi is the Hereditary Trustee of the Rajan Kattalai of Sri Thiyagarajaswami Temple.

anchor.surface_text: By a writ petition filed by the appellant, Sri-la-Sri Subramania Desika Gnana Sambanda Pandarasannadhi, Hereditary Trustee of the Rajan Kattalai of the temple in question, in the High Court of Madras the validity of this latter numberification was challenged.

facts.text: Madras High Court rejected the appellant's pleas and dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has rejected the pleas raised by the appellant in support of his case that the impugned numberification is invalid, and has dismissed the writ petition filed by him.

facts.text: Sri Thiyagarajaswami Temple is in Tiruvarur, Thanjavur District, an ancient temple with specific endowments called Kattalais.

anchor.surface_text: In the town of Tiruvarur in Thanjavur Dist. there is an ancient temple. The Presiding Deity is Sri Thyagarajaswami. A distinguishing feature of this temple is that apart from an allowance called the Mohini allowance, there is numberother property which can be treated as devoted for its general maintenance.

facts.text: There are 13 Kattalais in the temple including Rajan Kattalai, Ulthurai Kattalai, Abisheka Kattalai and Annadanam Kattalai.

anchor.surface_text: A large number of specific endowments called Kattalais with specific reference to special services in the temple, its festivities and several charities in glorification of the principal deity, have however been made in respect of this temple. It is said that there are 13 such Kattalais, the important amongst them being Rajan Kattalai, Ulthurai Kattalai, Abisheka Kattalai and Annadanam Kattalai.

facts.text: Management of each Kattalai is vested in hereditary trustee(s); trusteeship of Rajan Kattalai vests in head of Dharmapuram mutt.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the management of each one of these Kattalais is vested in a certain Trustee or Trustees hereditarily. The trusteeship of Rajan Kattalai vests in the head of the Dharmapuram mutt in the Thanjavur district.

facts.text: In 1910, a suit under s.92 CPC was filed in Sub-Court at Thanjavur for scheme to manage temple affairs; scheme settled and confirmed by High Court on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: As a result. in 1910, a suit was flied under s.92 of the Code of Civil Procedure for the settlement of a scheme to manage the affairs of the temple in the Sub-Court at Thanjavur. A scheme was accordingly settled. and when the matter was taken in appeal, the High Court substantially companyfirmed the said scheme  vide Gnana Sambanda v. Vaithilinga Mudaliar .

facts.text: In 1931, another suit under s.92 CPC in District Court, East Thanjavur for modification of the scheme; modifications made.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1931, there was another suit under s.92 of the Code on the file of the District Court, East Thanjavur for the modification of the scheme already framed. It was urged that certain defects in the scheme had been numbericed in the actual working, and so, it was necessary to make some modifications. Accordingly, some modifications were made.

facts.text: Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927 (Madras Act II of 1927) passed; amended by Act IX of 1937 adding Chapter VI-A.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, the Madras Legislature passed the Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927. ... This Act was amended by Madras Act IX of 1937. The result of the amendment was that Chapter VI-A was added to the Act of 1927.

facts.text: On May 25, 1937, notification issued under Chapter VI-A bringing temple and Kattalais under Board control.

anchor.surface_text: on May 25, 1937, a numberification was issued. To this numberification we have already referred.

facts.text: Executive Officer appointed by Board on July 12, 1937; powers defined on July 30, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this numberification, an Executive Officer was appointed by the Board on July 12, 1937. On July 30, 1937, the Board defined the powers of the Executive Officer and directed him to take charge and be in possession of the temple and the various Kattalais attached thereto.

facts.text: Pandarasannadhi of Dharmapuram Mutt instituted S. No. 20 of 1938 in Madras High Court challenging the 1937 notification; compromise decree passed on August 1, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The Pandarasannadhi of the Dharmapuram Mutt who was then the hereditary Trustee of the Rajan Kattalai instituted S. No. 20 of 1938 in the Madras High Court ... This companypromise decree was passed on August 1, 1940

facts.text: Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927 repealed by Act XIX of 1951 effective September 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: After the Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950,the Hindu Religious Endowments Act of 1927 was repealed and in its place Act XIX of 1951 was substituted. This latter Act came into force on September 30. 1951.

facts.text: Amending Act No. IX of 1956 substituted s.64(4) allowing continuation of notifications for further periods not exceeding five years.

anchor.surface_text: In 1956, another Amending Act  No. IX of 1956  was passed. Section 2 of this Amending Act substituted a new sub-section in the place of s.64 4 . Under that provision, every numberification published or deemed to be published under that section shall remain in force for a period of five years. but it may by numberification be cancelled at any time or companytinued from time to time for a further period or periods number exceeding five years at a time

facts.text: Appellant challenged validity of 1956 notification in writ petition on grounds including lack of opportunity to be heard.

anchor.surface_text: Two principal companytentions were urged before the High Court by the, appellant in support of his plea that the impugned numberification is invalid. ... The second ground which was urged by the appellant was that the numberification was issued without giving an opportunity to the appellant to show cause why the earlier numberification should number be extended.

facts.text: High Court held proceedings under s.64(4) quasi-judicial requiring opportunity to be heard but refused writ as point not raised and notification expiring soon.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court has found in favour of the appellant that the proceedings authorised to be taken under s.64 4  are in the nature of quasi-judicial proceedings. ... The High Court refused to uphold the said point for the other reason that the impugned numberification would soon expire on September 30, 1961

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, and directed issuance of writ quashing the August 4, 1956 notification.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court, and direct that an appropriate writ or order be issued quashing the numberification issued by the respondent State on August 4, 1956.

facts.text: Madras Act XXII of 1959 came into force on January 1, 1960, affecting continuation of notifications.

anchor.surface_text: before it delivered its judgment, a new Act had companye into force  Madras Act XXII of 1959 . This Act came into operation on January I, 1960.

facts.text: Compromise in S.No.20/1938 restored possession of Kattalai properties to trustee subject to Executive Officer supervision.

anchor.surface_text: In substance, as a result of the companypromise, the numberification was maintained, but the possession of the Kattalai properties was restored to the Trustee who was to manage the same by a staff under his companytrol. and had to keep accounts.

facts.text: Head of Dharmapuram mutt manages 27 temples through deputies; for Rajan Kattalai, through Kattalai Thambiran.

anchor.surface_text: The head of this mutt is known as Pandarasannadhi and under his management there are about 27 temples. ... With regard to the services companynected with the Rajan Kattalai in Sri Thyagarajaswami temple at Thiruvarur, the head of Dharmapuram mutt generally functions through a deputy known as Kattalai Thambiran.

issues.text: Whether s.64 of the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 is constitutionally invalid as it empowers the State to take away the right of property in hereditary trusteeship under Article 19(1)(f) of the Constitution in an arbitrary manner

anchor.surface_text: Two principal contentions were urged before the High Court by the, appellant in support of his plea that the impugned notification is invalid. It was argued that the trusteeship of the Rajan Kattalai being hereditary in the head of the Dharmapuram Mutt. is a right of property under Art. 19 i  f  of the Constitution, and since s.64 of the Act empowers the respondent State to take away that right of property in an arbitrary and capricious manner. that provision is Constitutionally invalid.

issues.text: Whether the proceedings and order under s.64(4) of the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 are quasi-judicial in nature requiring compliance with principles of natural justice including notice and opportunity to be heard

anchor.surface_text: the proceedings authorised to be taken under s.64 4  are in the nature of quasi-judicial proceedings.  and the order which can be passed under the said provision is a quasijudicial order and so, the High Court conceded that before making such an order, it was necessary that the appellant should have been given an opportunity to be heard, for that is the requirement of natural justice

issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in refusing to quash the impugned notification under s.64(4) on the grounds that the plea was not raised and that the notification would expire soon

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri for the appellant contends that both the grounds given by the High Court in support of its refusal to issue a writ are plainly erroneous... We are, therefore, satisfied that the High Court should have granted the prayer made by the appellant for the issue of an appropriate writ cancelling the impugned notification.

arguments.claim: The trusteeship of the Rajan Kattalai being hereditary in the head of the Dharmapuram Mutt is a right of property under Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution, and s.64 of the Act empowers the respondent State to take away that right of property in an arbitrary and capricious manner, that provision is constitutionally invalid

anchor.surface_text: Two principal contentions were urged before the High Court by the, appellant in support of his plea that the impugned notification is invalid. arguments.court_reasoning: That case involved materially different sections; here s.64(3) and s.64(4) similar in nature and process

arguments.claim: s.64(4) quasi-judicial like s.64(3) because Government must consider whether case made for cancelling or extending notification based on relevant facts each time, requiring hearing trustee per natural justice

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that just as while acting under s.64 3  the Government has ultimately to companysider whether a case has been made out for the issue of a numberification, so while acting under s.64 4 , Government has to companysider whether a case has been made out for cancelling the numberification or for extending it.

holdings.text: Proceedings under s.64(4) of the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 are quasi-judicial in nature and require compliance with principles of natural justice, including giving notice and opportunity to be heard to the trustee before issuing a notification to continue a prior notification.

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that just as while acting under s.64 3  the Government has ultimately to consider whether a case has been made out for the issue of a notification, so while acting under s.64 4 , Government has to consider whether a case has been made out for cancelling the notification or for extending it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The process under s.64(4) is identical to s.64(3) requiring consideration of relevant facts on each occasion whether to cancel or extend notification; trustee must be heard as per natural justice; rejects distinction argued by respondent.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in holding that the specific plea of no opportunity to be heard was not raised in the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The first reason, as we have already indicated, is that the High Court thought that the plea in question had not been raised by the appellant in his writ petition. This reason is no doubt, technically right in the sense that this plea was not mentioned in the first affidavit filed by the appellant in support of his petition but in the affidavit-in-rejoinder filed by the appellant this plea has been expressly taken.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea expressly taken in affidavit-in-rejoinder; respondents had full notice when argued before High Court.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in refusing the writ on the ground that the impugned notification would expire soon on September 30, 1961, as Madras Act XXII of 1959 s.72(7) extended its validity beyond that date.

anchor.surface_text: The second reason given by the High Court appears to be plainly erroneous. In assuming that the impugned Order would come to an end on September 30, 1961, the High Court appears to have ignored the fact that before it delivered its judgment, a new Act had come into force  Madras Act XXII of 1959 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1959 Act came into force January 1, 1960 before High Court judgment; s.72(7) validates and continues prior notifications under new Act.

holdings.text: The High Court should have issued an appropriate writ quashing the impugned notification dated August 4, 1956 issued under s.64(4).

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the High Court should have granted the prayer made by the appellant for the issue of an appropriate writ cancelling the impugned notification. Though the impugned notification has been issued in 1956 for five years, its life gets statutorily extended,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both reasons of High Court erroneous; violation of natural justice renders notification invalid; quashing necessary to allow appellant opportunity to show cause against extension.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; direct issuance of writ quashing the notification issued by respondent State on August 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court, and direct that an appropriate writ or order be issued quashing the notification issued by the respondent State on August 4, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conclusion based on holdings that s.64(4) requires natural justice which was violated without hearing, and High Court wrongly refused relief.

anchor.surface_text: vide Gnana Sambanda v. Vaithilinga Mudaliar .  1  The scheme thus framed governed the management of the temple thereafter. It appears that the affairs of the said temple again came up for companysideration before the Madras High Court in Ramanathan Chettiar v. Balayee Ammal 2 . In that case, the High Court rejected the companytention of one of the Kattalai trustees that subject to the performance of services, the endowments in question had to be treated as his .property the view taken by the High Court on this occasion was that all the Kattalais were appendages of the temple though each Kattalaidar was a separate trustee, there was numberquestion of private ownership.

In the year 1931, there was another suit under s.92 of the Code on the file of the District Court, East Thanjavur for the modification of the scheme already framed.  1  1928 18 L.W. 247.  2  1923 27 L.W. 33.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Radeshyam Khare Anr. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh and Others.  1  In that case, it was held that ss. 53A and 57 of the C.P. and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, differed materially in their scope and effect, and that the nature of the orders which can be passed under the two respective sections was number the same. That is why this Court found that whereas in taking action under s.53A the State Government was required to act judicially, the same companyld number be said to be true about s.57. We do number see how this decision can afford any assistance to Mr. Chetty in support of his argument that s.64 4  is entirely different  1 1959 S.C.R. 1440.

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that just as while acting under s.64 3  the Government has ultimately to consider whether a case has been made out for the issue of a notification, so while acting under s.64 4 , Government has to consider whether a case has been made out for cancelling the notification or for extending it.

In the result, we allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court, and direct that an appropriate writ or order be issued quashing the numberification issued by the respondent State on August 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The first reason, as we have already indicated, is that the High Court thought that the plea in question had not been raised by the appellant in his writ petition. This reason is no doubt, technically right in the sense that this plea was not mentioned in the first affidavit filed by the appellant in support of his petition but in the affidavit-in-rejoinder filed by the appellant this plea has been expressly taken.

In the result, we allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court, and direct that an appropriate writ or order be issued quashing the numberification issued by the respondent State on August 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The second reason given by the High Court appears to be plainly erroneous. In assuming that the impugned Order would come to an end on September 30, 1961, the High Court appears to have ignored the fact that before it delivered its judgment, a new Act had come into force  Madras Act XXII of 1959 .

In the result, we allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court, and direct that an appropriate writ or order be issued quashing the numberification issued by the respondent State on August 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the High Court should have granted the prayer made by the appellant for the issue of an appropriate writ cancelling the impugned notification. Though the impugned notification has been issued in 1956 for five years, its life gets statutorily extended,

In the result, we allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court, and direct that an appropriate writ or order be issued quashing the numberification issued by the respondent State on August 4, 1956.
